captions.text: Hello Internet,

I want to talk about Canada who this week
made my reason-to-like her list one item longer
by deciding to abolish the penny.

Since I previously made a video called 'Death
to Pennies' it should come as no surprise

that this move gets a big 'Go Canada!' from
me.

So lets take a moment to cheer Canada for
her economic rationalism, look at how getting

rid of a coin works in practice, and remind
her sister to the South why she might want
to do the same.

Canada's plan is pretty simple: in a couple
months the Royal Canadian Mint will switch

the penny making machine from on, to off.
That's it.

Pretty much nothing else in the world is going
to change. Pennies will still be be legal

tender in Canada, so that jar of several hundred
that you'll never bother to count will always
be worth just as much as it is today.

And In shops there will still be that person
who pays with exact change.

But after they've tediously counted out their
precious (worthless) pennies the shop will

send them to back to the Royal Canadian Mint
to be melted down. Thus the supply of pennies

will slowly decrease over time in pleasant
half-life curve.

But, while the penny will functionally go
away, prices listed in one-cent intervals
will not.

Your coffee and TimBits will still cost the
same and when you get to the cash register

the total amount after tax will still have
single cents.

And if you pay by card, that exact amount
will be deducted from your account.

The only difference is if you pay in cash,
not card, *and* you don't have any pennies

with which to waste everyone else's time then
the price will be rounded to the nearest five
cents.

And yes, in rounding sometimes you win and
sometimes you lose but -- and this is the

rather salient point -- either way a one or
two cent difference isn't worth caring about.

Which is why Canada can safely jettison the
penny in the first place.

Inevitably, thought, this is the point in
the discussion when pro-penny people propose

that ditching the worthless coin will make
prices go up and your savings go down.

But the evidence for this claim is nonexistent
because many countries have done this before
with no ill effect.

Sure, coin collectors and inefficiency fans
will be sad to see the penny go but overall

it's a big win for Canada because printing
money isn't free. The cost to make a one-cent
penny is 1.6 cents.

So every year when Canada visited the mint
she spent 29 million dollars to buy 18 million

dollars worth of pennies -- effectively throwing
away 11 million dollars a year.

Now, obviously ditching pennies won't single-handedly
balance the budget but it's the easiest most
rational place to start.

Congratulations Canada! May others follow
in your path.
P.S.

If you want to know more about why the United
States in particular should get rid of pennies

you can either watch my video on the topic
or listen to fellow penny-hater John Green

get arm-wavingly angry about not only pennies,
but also nickels, which are even worse.

Also There should be a new main video up in
the next week or two but if you want to help

me make them faster you go here on my website
to help out with the fact-checking for upcoming
projects.
Thanks for watching.

comments.text:
Its costs more make penny than its worth and than again, something which

rate wage' citizen?!﻿
comments.author: Dav Rock

comments.text:
+Dav Rock No you don't. Buy ten items at $1.57 each, that's $15.70, which 
is a multiple of 5 cents, so rounding will leave it unchanged. Buy eleven 
at the same price, that'll come to $17.27, which will get rounded to 
$17.25, giving you two cents off.

Now, if you buy one item at $1.57 *as a single transaction* ten times, that 
will result in you getting charged $1.55 * 10 = 15.50 over those ten 
purchases. But seriously, how often do you buy a single item that cheap? 
Not that often I'll wager. More likely, it's part of a much longer list of 
items, which will randomise the last digit and with it the amount of 
rounding needed (which with 5 cents as the smallest coin will be no more 
than two cents in either direction).
comments.author: Roxor128

We have "kroner" and "øre" which directly translated means crowns and ears.

A looong time ago with started getting rid of 1 øre and so forth.
A couple of years ago we got rid of our coin for 25 øre, and now the 
smallest coin in Denmark is 50 øre and after that 1 krone.
In the near future we will probably get rid of the 50 øre, because almost 
nothing costs 50 øre anymore!﻿

comments.author: SilentBudgie

comments.text:
+zh11147  Why not? Just calculate the tax on the item before you put it on 
the shelf and adjust the local advertising appropriately. Instead of 
pricing it at $10 and adding $1 in tax at the cash register, price it at 
$11 and skip the register calculation.

I still don't get why you think people would be getting ripped off by 
rounding. If you're buying 120 items which total $587.68 when doing the 
shopping, and you pay cash, you'll be getting charged $587.70. It's only 
two cents. Next to what your bill came to, it's nothing. The next time it 
might come to $565.37 and you get rounded down to $565.35 and save two 
cents. I don't see the problem.
comments.author: Roxor128

comments.text:
+Roxor128 Well, the laws in the USA are...different (and by different, I 
mean really fucking complicated!) Anyway, taxes vary by state and county, 
so businesses can't advertise the final price of their goods after taxes, 
nor can they price them to the nearest 5 cents. But, because people would 
launch several successful lawsuits because they got ripped off if the 
businesses rounded up, most companies would either have to keep older 
pennies on hand, to give exact change, or round down. 
But, the government does not have the authority to force businesses to 
round their prices down. Because of this, if there were ever a law that 
makes it illegal to round up to the nearest five cents (in America, the 
courts make laws, because we stand by the concept of "stare decisis,") the 
government would be forced to give businesses back the money they lost in 
sales by constantly rounding their prices down in the form of tax refunds. 
They would have to do this, because like I said earlier, the US government 
does not have the authority to cut into the profits of a business, except 
through taxes and court issued damages.
comments.author: zh11147

comments.text:
+zh11147  I don't follow you. Why would they need to do those?

Nobody in Australia thinks they're getting ripped off by the fact that 
totals get rounded to the nearest five cents when they pay by cash. Back in 
the early 1990s when we got rid of the 1 and 2 cent coins, a lot of stores 
had stickers by the cash registers explaining how the rounding works.

0: unchanged
1: down to 0
2: down to 0
3: up to 5
4: up to 5
5: unchanged
6: down to 5
7: down to 5
8: up to next 0
9: up to next 0

Heck, some places like takeaway restaurants have all their prices ending in 
multiples of 5 cents so they don't have to bother with rounding at all.
comments.author: Roxor128

comments.text:
+Roxor128 I don't know, that's their problem and the reason businesses, 
would either have to keep a lot of pennies on hand, or always round down. 
But, if the second option is employed, a lot of huge companies will be 
getting a lot of money in tax refunds from the government, because you 
can't force them to always round down without subsidizing the costs, if 
that makes sense.
comments.author: zh11147

comments.text:
+zh11147  How are they going to do that without knowing how many items 
you're going to buy ahead of time? If everything is priced at $X.99, that 
last digit is going to be randomised by the number of items you end up 
buying.
comments.author: Roxor128

comments.text:
+Roxor128 It isn't; it's always going to be nice to round down, but almost

comments.author: zh11147

comments.text:
Half the time the customer pays more, half the time they pay less. It 
balances out in the end.

Now, getting rid of a five-cent coin is where you're going to get an 
imbalance. In New Zealand, businesses can choose which direction to round 
the fives, though most follow government advice and round it down. China 
uses a different approach and simply discards the last digit, giving 
customers an effective discount of up to nine cents.

It won't work in the US.  One, people here are too stupid to figure out how

comments.author: jdharm360

comments.text:
+zh11147 Prices that involve cents have always been psychological, a 
marketing invention. This will stay that way, the government has no say in 
this. A company would just be obligated to charge 5 dollars for a product 
that's 4.99 on the shelf, or 4.95 for a product that's 4.96. It won't be a 
big deal because the difference of a cent on many products together can 
either end up on the 1/2 or on the 3/4, thus leaving it still in the hands 
of the consumer to, if you will, decide on whether or not he/she wants to 
spend 1/2 cents extra, or gain 1/2 cents. In practice this balances out. Of 
course, there's all kinds of crazy hypotheses that people can come up with 
with regards to penny abolition, but the fact of the matter is, is that a 
lot of countries have gotten rid of their pennies before and nothing has 
happened to their economy. If you look at the common European market for 
example, some countries still accept pennies (France, Spain), other 
countries don't (Netherlands, Finland). There are of course price 
differences between those countries, but those have exactly 0 to do with 
the existence of pennies.

comments.author: kitrana

comments.text:
Don't purchase things from those locations. I've worked a couple jobs 
having to do with cash handling, and we've always rounded to the closest 5 
cents, whether that meant up or down. The irritating bit was the conspiracy 
theorists who thought we changed our prices subtly so that there was a 
higher chance we'd be rounding up on each transaction. The truth is, 2 
pennies isn't worth anyone's time.

comments.author: Firstname Lastname

comments.text:
Pennies cost 1.8 cents to make each. They are worth 1 cent.
Nickels cost 11.2 cents to make each. They are worth 5 cents.
Dimes cost 5.7 cents to make each. They are worth 10 cents.
Quarters cost 12 cents to make each. they are worth 25 cents.
Bills cost about between 5 and 12 cents each. They are worth between 1 and 
100$.

Nickels and Pennies are not cost efficient. However the Bills make up for 
it. Perhaps they help reduce inflation by not producing as much new money?  

The perfect ratio of new money produced should be equal to the amount of 
new worth produced in the county, the cost of make the money and the amount 
of destroyed money each year. The value of the dollar is decreasing so we 
are making more than we need.

Eliminating the penny and nickel does not add more worth to a country, but 
makes the higher valued coins worth less. Your twenty will buy less than 
before.﻿

comments.author: Sarah Shepherd

comments.text:
New Zealand did it quite a few years ago. and we also got rid of our 5 cent 
coin also  But inflation since my youth is such that the new 10 c piece is 
worth about as much as a penny was when I was a boy in the 1960's

rounding is no problem though we use Swedish rounding, (if memory serves, 
it is so commonplace we don't notice it anymore) 1-5 c goes down 6 to 9 
goes up.

so our 10 c piece is the new penny  and whereas one pound was a lot of 
money when I was a boy  2 dollars (its equivalent, we went decimal in 1967) 
is now small change.﻿

comments.text: Rounding: ↑ ↑ ↓ ↓ ← → ← → B A﻿

comments.text:
Can someone explain the rounding chart shown at 1:16? I thought if it ends 
1-4 round down and 5-9 round up?﻿
comments.author: xtheresaxo

comments.text:
The rule you're thinking about is rounding to the nearest 10 but we're 
rounding to the nearest 5. We still have 5 cent coins so if the price ends 
in 5 you don't round at all. 1&2 round down to 0, 3&4 round up to 5, 6&7 
round down to 5, 8&9 round up to 10.
